trivia: All languages function as neuter nouns.
Mark refers to a borderland or march.
Related to the English word "build"—the form of something.
Anything ending in -chen is neuter and means "little." It's a "little bread."
Words ending in -o are usually neuter.
Remember: das Zimmer rule applies here too.
Think of "gold"—money and gold are both neuter (das).
Words starting with Ge- and ending in -e are often neuter.
Zimmer (room) is neuter; therefore Hotelzimmer is neuter.

sentence: Mein Auto hat das Kennzeichen L-ZB 6168.

trivia: Words ending in -o (often loanwords) are usually neuter.
Words ending in -ert are often neuter.
Words ending in -ment are usually neuter (das).
Latin-origin words ending in -um are always neuter (das).
Most countries are neuter and usually don't use the article.
Loanwords from French/English are often neuter (das).
A famous Austrian/German dish. The word is the same in English.
Academic terms from Latin are frequently neuter.
Solar + Auto. Compound words take the gender of the last word (das Auto).
Like the word "Spiel" (a sales pitch or performance).
Think of a "Stick" —a portion of something.
Most sports in German are neuter (das).
Most venues for art/history are neuter (das).

sentence: Hast du ein Wasser für mich?
trivia: Das Wasser is a perfect cognate. Neuter gender.
Wörter (words) + Buch (book). A book of words.
Cognate with "Center." Words ending in -um are usually neuter.
Think of "timber" (what rooms were made of). Neuter.
The female version is die Ärztin.
Words ending in -icht are often masculine.
Nouns ending in -er describing people are usually masculine.
Bild (picture) + Schirm (shield). A shield for pictures!

sentence: Felix ist der Bruder von Sarah.

trivia: Masculine loanword. Pronounced like English but with a "k" sound.

sentence: Bist du ein Einwohner von Berlin?
trivia: Refers to someone living in a place.
Currency names in German are usually masculine.
Hafen is masculine, so Flughafen is too.
Related to the verb grüßen. Masculine.
Almost identical to English, just remember it's masculine (der).
German cheesecake uses Quark, making it fluffier than US style.
Lippen (lips) + Stift (pen). A pen for your lips!
The person who does the malen.

sentence: Das ist der Mann von Lucie.

trivia: Refers to any person regardless of gender.
All days of the week are masculine (der).
All times of day are masculine (except die Nacht).
Roller comes from the verb rollen (to roll).

sentence: Ben ist der Onkel von Sarah.

trivia: Compounds take the gender of the last word: der Saft -> der Orangensaft.

sentence: Hast du einen Platz für mich?

trivia: Related to "close" (schließen). A key closes things.
Schokolade + Kuchen. Words ending in -en are often masculine.

sentence: Felix ist der Sohn von Peter.

trivia: Sonne (sun) + Schirm (shield). Like a rain-shield, but for sun.
General term for any writing utensil.
Most hot caffeinated drinks are masculine (der).
Often used in the plural (Angaben). Feminine.
Look for the big red "A" symbol in Germany.
Abstract nouns ending in -t are often feminine.
Bank can mean a financial bank or a park bench!
Ends in -ung, so it is feminine (die).
Think of a "purse" (Börse) where money is handled.
Short for Coca-Cola; feminine in German.
A modern career term: Daten + Analystin.

sentence: Peter und Lucie sind die Eltern.
trivia: Only exists in the plural form in German.
Karte ends in -e, so it’s feminine (die).

sentence: Das ist Lucie, die Frau von Peter.
Susanne und Ben sind die Geschwister.
trivia: German has a single word for brothers and sisters combined.
Always feminine because Stadt is feminine.
Ends in -e, so it is feminine (die).
Words ending in -ion are always feminine (die).
Ends in -ik, so it is feminine (die).
Words ending in -enz are almost always feminine (die).
Ends in -e, so it is feminine (die).
Perfect cognate. Ends in -e, so it's feminine.

english: The painting / The art of painting
trivia: Words ending in -ei are always feminine (die).
Though it doesn't end in -e, Nacht is feminine.
English loanword; usually feminine in German (die).
Ends in -ion, which is almost always feminine in German.

sentence: Hast du Angst vor der Prüfung?
trivia: Ends in -ung, so it is feminine (die).
Always used with the feminine article die.

sentence: Sarah ist die Schwester von Felix.

trivia: Think of the "Side" of a leaf of paper.
Ends in -e, so it is feminine (die).
Ends in -e, so it is feminine.
Not to be confused with Uhr (clock/o'clock).

sentence: Susanne ist die Tante von Felix.

trivia: Modern slang: "In der Tasche" can mean "it's a done deal."
Related to "dish" via older roots. Feminine.

sentence: Sarah ist die Tochter von Lucie.

trivia: One of the few feminine countries (die Türkei).
Ends in -ung, which is always feminine in German.
Cognate of "hour," but used for the physical device too.
Words ending in -tät are always feminine.
Cognate of the English "tide" (as in Yuletide).
Zimmer + Karte. Gender is determined by die Karte.
Reich means empire or realm (The Frankish Realm).
Land is a common suffix for country names.
A compound of Groß (Great) and Britannien.
Like most countries, it is neuter (das Spanien).
The short form of the Czech Republic.
Masculine people, but the country is neuter.
Plural noun. Singular is das Datum.

word: Er lebt jetzt allein in Köln.
sentence: Er lebt jetzt allein in Köln.

trivia: "Machen" = to make. The deal is "made off" (finished).
The German "OK." If everything is "clear," it's understood.
Kann is the modal verb for ability or possibility.

english: Andreas stays overnight in the hotel.

trivia: "Hören" = Hear. You use this only on the phone.
Use this instead of Auf Wiedersehen when calling.

sentence: Sag mir bitte Bescheid, wenn du kommst.
trivia: Very common! "Bescheid" is like a "notice" or "decision."

english: Pictures are hanging in the museum.
sentence: Hängst du das Bild an die Wand?

trivia: Bald means "soon." Think of "boldly" coming soon.

sentence: Bist du sicher, dass das stimmt?
trivia: "Sicher" sounds like "Secure". If you are secure, you are sure.

word: Dann essen wir jetzt ein Schnitzel.
english: Then we'll eat a schnitzel now.

sentence: Der Lärm geht mir auf die Nerven!
trivia: Exactly the same as the English idiom.

sentence: Heute um drei? Das geht nicht.
trivia: "Gehen" = to go. If it doesn't "go," it doesn't work!

sentence: Ist das die Tasche von dir?
trivia: Von is used here to show possession.

sentence: Ich habe deinen Namen vergessen, das ist mir peinlich.
trivia: "Peinlich" is related to "Pain." It's painful to be embarrassed.
Literally "That is sausage to me." Germans love sausage so much it's their "whatever."

sentence: Der Film ist super, das lohnt sich!
trivia: "Lohn" means "wage/reward." If it gives a reward, it's worth it.
A common way to agree on a plan.
"It makes nothing." Similar to "It's nothing" in English.

sentence: Sagst du mir, was das zusammen macht?
trivia: Macht (makes) is used for the total, just like in English.

sentence: Ich finde das teuer, aber das sehe ich anders!
trivia: In Arabic: "Ana ara dhalika bi-shakl akhar" (أنا أرى ذلك بشكل آخر).

sentence: Das sehe ich anders als du.

trivia: "Stimmt" sounds like "Stem." The truth is the stem of the facts.

english: That used to be your favorite painter.

sentence: Ehrlich, das war keine gute Idee.

english: The code is (written) on the card.
trivia: Stehen (to stand) is used for text "standing" on a page.

english: The IT specialist develops computer games.

sentence: Ich bin müde, deshalb bleibe ich zu Hause.
Auf welchem Platz liegt dein Land?
trivia: Platz can mean place, square, or rank.

sentence: Weißt du, wie groß Deutschland ist?
trivia: Use groß for size/area, not just height.

sentence: Warst du schon in der Schweiz?
trivia: Most countries are neuter, but die Schweiz is feminine.

word: Schweiz ist so groß wie die Niederlande.
english: Switzerland is as large as the Netherlands.
sentence: Bist du so groß wie ich?
trivia: So... wie is the formula for "as... as."

english: The city has a large airport.

word: Stadt liegt in der Mitte von Deutschland.
english: The city lies in the middle of Germany.
sentence: Liegt deine Stadt in der Mitte?

english: The area code for Germany is 0049.
On Tuesdays we have a meeting.
trivia: Lowercase days with an 's' (dienstags) mean "every Tuesday."

sentence: Du hast recht, es ist kalt.

trivia: From French "Égal" (equal). It’s all "equal" to me.

sentence: Ehrlich gesagt, weiß ich es nicht.
trivia: "Ehrlich" is related to "Honor." Speaking with honor.

sentence: Eigentlich wollte ich heute Sport machen.
trivia: One of the most common words. "In reality/Actually."
Zeigen is to show or point out.

english: On one hand... on the other hand
sentence: Einerseits ist es gut, andererseits teuer.

trivia: Plural verbs end in -en, matching the infinitive.

sentence: Entweder wir gehen jetzt, oder gar nicht.
trivia: "Oder" is already "Or." Just remember "Entweder" starts the choice.

word: Er liest viele Bücher auf Englisch.
english: He reads many books in English.
trivia: Bücher is the plural of Buch.

sentence: Es freut mich, dass du Zeit hast.
trivia: A polite way to start a sentence.
Gibt comes from geben (to give). Literally "it gives."
In Germany, the 24-hour clock is standard for schedules.
Use nach for "past" the hour in time.

sentence: Es ist möglich, dass er kommt.

english: It is a quarter past twelve.
sentence: Gehen wir um Viertel nach zwölf?

english: It is a quarter to ten.
sentence: Kommst du um Viertel vor zehn?

english: It can’t go on like this

sentence: Es kann sein, dass er kommt.
Es kann sein, dass er kommt.
"Gehen wir heute spazieren?" - "Es kommt darauf an."
trivia: Literally "It comes down to it." Use it when you aren't sure.
Remember: In German, fun is something you "make" (machen).

sentence: Es tut mir leid für dich.

trivia: "Weh" is like "Woe." When you have woe, it hurts.
Landen is a perfect cognate of "to land."
Starten is used for both engines and journeys.

sentence: Bist du auch schon so alt?

trivia: The most common German word! Use it like "Exactly" or "Right."
Literally "Happily happened." It was my pleasure for it to happen.

sentence: Sagst du vor dem Schlafengehen "Gute Nacht"?
trivia: Note that "Nacht" is feminine, so it is "Gute," not "Guten."

sentence: Sagst du vor dem Essen "Guten Appetit"?
trivia: Often shortened to just "Appetit" in very casual settings.
The standard greeting until about 10:00 AM.

word: Guten Tag. Hier ist Otto Gruber.
english: Good day. This is Otto Gruber.
sentence: Sagst du deinen Namen am Telefon?
trivia: Standard way to identify yourself on a call.

english: Does Ms. Lustig have time tomorrow?
sentence: Hast du morgen Zeit für mich?
trivia: Morgen (lowercase) means tomorrow; Der Morgen (uppercase) is the morning.

english: Do you like listening to music?
sentence: Hörst du gern Musik beim Lernen?

trivia: Verbs ending in -ieren never take ge- in past tense.
Use als (as) when stating your job title.
German uses the 24-hour clock for business hours.

word: Ich arbeite von acht bis zwölf.
english: I work from eight to twelve.

trivia: Besuchen works for people AND events like conferences.

english: I am in Frankfurt for work.

word: Ich bin beruflich oft in Polen.
english: I am often in Poland for work.
trivia: Polen is the German name for Poland.

sentence: Das ist eine gute Idee, ich bin dafür.
Alle wollen Pizza, aber ich bin dagegen.

english: I am of the opinion that...
sentence: Ich bin der Meinung, dass das zu teuer ist.
trivia: "Meinung" = Opinion. Both start with 'O' sound in Arabic (Ra'y/Ra'yi).

sentence: Ich bin fertig mit der Arbeit.
trivia: "Fertig" sounds like "Verdict". The final word/end of a case.
Related to the verb scheiden (to separate).

sentence: Ich bin gleich da, warte bitte.

trivia: Ledig sounds like "let it be" (being free).

english: I am staying for one night.
I am staying for two nights.

trivia: Bleiben is a cognate of "leave" (as in "what is left behind").
Brauchen is a cognate of the archaic English word "brook" (to use/need).

english: I am eating a piece of cake.
trivia: The "i" in isst (du-form) is a stem change common in strong verbs.

sentence: Fährst du mit dem Bus ins Büro?
trivia: Büro is a loanword from French bureau.
Fahren is the root of "fare" (as in "thoroughfare").

sentence: Wann fängst du die Telekonferenz an?
trivia: Anfangen is a separable verb; the "an" goes to the very end.

sentence: Feierst du am Wochenende eine Party?
trivia: Feiern is a cognate of "fete" or "festival."
Finden is a perfect cognate of "to find."

sentence: Ich finde, dass das gut ist.
trivia: Just like in English, we "find" an idea to be good.

sentence: Wir sehen uns morgen? Ich freue mich darauf!

english: I eat breakfast at half past seven.
trivia: In German, halb acht means 7:30 (half towards 8).

sentence: Ich fühle mich heute nicht gut.

trivia: Ausgehen means going out for fun/socializing.

sentence: Gehst du heute in die Universität?

english: I am going to the cinema.
I am going to the museum.
trivia: Ins is a contraction of in das.

english: I am going to the restaurant.
trivia: French loanword, pronounced with a nasal "n" at the end.

english: I am going to the theater.
sentence: Gehst du mit mir ins Theater?
trivia: Theater is a cognate; just watch the "re" vs "er" spelling.

word: Ich glaube, Rom ist in Italien.
english: I believe Rome is in Italy.

sentence: Ich habe das Gefühl, dass er lügt.

trivia: Reservierung ends in -ung, making it feminine.
"Eilig" is related to "Haste." Think of a fast "Eagle" flying.

word: Ich habe jeden Tag eine Besprechung.
english: I have a meeting every day.
trivia: Jeden Tag indicates a recurring routine.
Add a "k" to eine to make it "none."

sentence: Ich kann nicht kommen, ich habe keine Zeit.
trivia: The most honest phrase in Germany!
"Hätte" is related to "had". Like saying "I would have gladly..."
Heißen is used for names; it literally means "to be called."

sentence: Ich hoffe, dass alles gut wird.
Ich kann das für dich machen.

trivia: Können is a modal verb; it pushes the second verb (spielen) to the end.
Kaufen is a cognate of the old English word "chapman" (merchant).
Aus is the preposition for country/city of origin.
Leben refers to a long-term state of living.

english: I am reading information about Frankfurt.
I love my wife very much.
trivia: Lieben is the root of the word "lovely."

english: I would like a double room, please.
trivia: Doppel is a direct cognate of "double."

english: I would like a single room, please.
I would like an orange juice, please.
trivia: Saft (juice) sounds like "soft" drinks, but it's just the juice!

word: Ich möchte bitte mit Frau Lustig sprechen.
english: I would like to speak with Ms. Lustig, please.
I would like to present a project idea.

trivia: A common way to confirm a booking at the desk.
Use doch before this to mean "Actually, I will!"
Nehmen (to take) changes to nimmst for du.
Parken is a loanword from English.

english: I am researching on the internet.
trivia: From the French rechercher. All -ieren verbs are regular.

word: Ich rede über Arbeit und Familie.
english: I am talking about work and family.
sentence: Redest du oft über deine Arbeit?

trivia: The verb schlafen changes its vowel to ä for du (schläfst).

sentence: Ich schlage vor, dass wir eine Pause machen.
trivia: "Schlagen" = to hit. You "hit" a suggestion onto the table.
Berichte is the plural of Bericht.
A very common, warm way to end a message.
Singen is a perfect cognate of "sing."

english: I am sitting in the library.
sentence: Sitzt du oft in der Bibliothek?

english: I speak a little bit of German.

trivia: Use perfekt just like the English adjective.
Most languages in German end in -isch.

word: Ich stehe um sieben Uhr auf.
english: I get up at seven o'clock.

trivia: Studieren is specifically for university-level study.

english: I am looking for a hotel room.
I am talking on the phone with Klaus.
trivia: Use telefonieren for the act of being on a call.

sentence: Trinkst du einen Tee mit mir?
trivia: Tee is a direct cognate. Easy to remember!

english: I am staying overnight in the hotel.
trivia: Nacht (night) is inside the verb übernachten.

english: I am repeating the phone number.

trivia: Use in for the city you currently reside in.
Bar is related to "bare" (cold, hard cash).

english: I am paying with a credit card.
trivia: Kredit + Karte. Very similar to English.

sentence: Du ziehst nach Berlin? Im Ernst?
trivia: "Ernst" = Earnest. Are you in an earnest state?

sentence: Gibt es eine Bank in der Nähe?

word: In Frankfurt gibt es viele Museen und Banken.
english: In Frankfurt, there are many museums and banks.
sentence: Gibt es in deiner Stadt Banken?
trivia: Es gibt (there is/are) always takes accusative.

sentence: Lebst du auch in einer Stadt?
Zahlst du den Preis mit Frühstück?

trivia: Da refers back to the place mentioned.
Stimmen means "to be correct" or "to tune/vote."
Same meaning as English, easy win

sentence: Tut mir leid, ich habe keine Ahnung.
trivia: "Ahnung" is like "notion". Arabic: "Ma ‘indi fikra" (ما عندي فكرة).

english: No desire / Don't feel like it
sentence: Ich habe keine Lust auf Hausaufgaben.

trivia: "Sorge" is like "Sorrow." Don't have any sorrow/worry.
Student refers specifically to university level.

english: Come with me for a second
sentence: Ich zeige dir das Büro. Komm mal mit.
trivia: "Mal" softens the command, making it "Come along" instead of "COME!"
The polite "Können." Always use the "-ten" ending for strangers.
Informal greeting for a female friend.
Informal greeting for a male friend.
"Lust" in German just means "pleasure/desire," not just the English "lust."
Literally "Make it well." Arabic: "Dir balak" (دير بالك).

english: Max is going to the doctor.
trivia: Zum is a contraction of zu dem.

word: Mein Auto hat das Kennzeichen L-ZB 6168.
english: My car has the license plate L-ZB 6168.

sentence: Ist dein Name schwer zu schreiben?
Ist dein Studium auch auf Deutsch?
trivia: Studium refers to the degree program itself.

sentence: Meiner Meinung nach ist das ein Fehler.
trivia: Note: The verb comes immediately after this phrase!
Mir geht’s = “to me it goes” (German logic 🤯)
The standard formal closing for emails/letters.

english: Do you really want no chocolate cake?

sentence: "Magst du ihn?" - "Na ja, er ist okay."
trivia: The ultimate German filler. Used when you're hesitant.

word: Nein, da war ich noch nicht.
english: No, I haven't been there yet.
sentence: Warst du noch nicht in Berlin?
Sie ist nicht nur nett, sondern auch klug.
Das Wetter ist heute schön, nicht wahr?
trivia: Like the English "..., right?" or French "n'est-ce pas?".

sentence: Obwohl es kalt ist, trägt er ein T-Shirt.
trivia: Sends the verb to the end! "Ob" (if) + "wohl" (well).

sentence: Wie viele Einwohner hat deine Stadt?

english: Peter is studying for the exam.
trivia: Für always takes the accusative case.
Prima is an informal way to say "great."

word: Rufen Sie bitte am Montag wieder an.
sentence: Rufst du mich morgen wieder an?

trivia: The most formal way to start a letter.
Common in Bavaria and Austria; comes from Latin for "servant."

word: Sie fährt meistens mit dem Motorroller.

trivia: Specific to the act of teaching a class.

word: Stehst du morgen um 8.00 Uhr auf?
english: Are you getting up at 8:00 tomorrow?
sentence: Warum stehst du so früh auf?
trivia: In yes/no questions, the verb takes "Position 1".

sentence: Es regnet, aber ich gehe trotzdem joggen.
trivia: Arabic: "Ma' dhalika" (مع ذلك). It's a "rebel" word.
The most common informal way to say goodbye.

sentence: Tut mir leid, ich komme spät.

word: Ich lerne Deutsch, um in Berlin zu arbeiten.
english: I learn german in order to work in Berlin.
sentence: Ich lerne Deutsch, um in Berlin zu arbeiten.
trivia: Use this to explain your purpose.
"Erfolg" = Success. Use this for tasks, "Viel Glück" for games.
"Glück" sounds like "Luck" if you swap the G for L.
"Spaß" sounds like "Space". You need space to have fun!

english: The car is way too expensive
sentence: Das Auto ist viel zu teuer.

word: Vielleicht können wir ins Museum gehen.
english: Perhaps we can go to the museum.
Day before yesterday / Day after tomorrow

sentence: Wann beginnst du mit dem Lernen?

trivia: A vital phrase for making plans.

word: Wann ist die Besprechung zu Ende?
Wann können wir ins Museum gehen?
english: When can we go to the museum?
trivia: In questions, the modal verb takes "Position 2".

word: Warst du schon mal in München?
english: Have you ever been to Munich?
sentence: Warst du schon mal in München?

word: Was für ein Auto hast du?
english: What kind of car do you have?
sentence: Was für ein Auto hast du?
trivia: "What for a...?" Think of it as "What [category] for a [thing]?"

sentence: Was hältst du von meinem neuen Plan?
trivia: "Halten" = to hold. "What do you hold of this?"

word: Was kostet das Zimmer pro Nacht?
english: What does the room cost per night?
sentence: Weißt du, was das Zimmer kostet?
trivia: Pro is used just like in English (per).

english: What are you doing on Monday?
trivia: Days of the week always use the preposition am.

english: What do you like to do?
sentence: Was machst du gern in deiner Freizeit?
trivia: Gern indicates you enjoy the action.

sentence: Was meinst du zu diesem Film?

english: What would you like to drink?
trivia: Möchten is a polite form of wollen; think of it as "would like."
Sprache (language) is related to sprechen (to speak).

english: Which telephone number does Ms. Esser have?

trivia: Use this to ask for someone's identity informally.
Short for "Wie geht es dir?". Think of it as "How goes it?"

english: How long does the concert last?
What do you mean by that?

sentence: Wie nennt man das auf Deutsch?
trivia: A lifesaver when you forget a word. "Name" = "Nennt".

sentence: Weißt du, wie spät es ist?

word: Wie viel kostet ein Stück Käsekuchen?
english: How much does a piece of cheesecake cost?
sentence: Weißt du, wie viel der Käsekuchen kostet?
trivia: Käse = Cheese, Kuchen = Cake. Just like English!

sentence: Warst du schon in der Hauptstadt?
Tut mir leid, wir können nichts machen.

english: We would like to pay (the bill).
trivia: Bezahlen is used specifically for paying a specific bill/amount.
Zahlen is related to "tally" (counting the numbers).
Treiben is the specific verb for "doing" sport.
Wohnen is for your specific address or city.
Use woher for origin and wo for location.
Zusammen sounds a bit like "summing" things together.

sentence: Zuerst frühstücke ich, dann arbeite ich.
trivia: The "Storyteller's Kit." Use these to describe your day.
Related to "Service" in a restaurant context.

word: Ich esse mittags in der Kantine.
english: I eat in the cafeteria at noon.
sentence: Isst du mittags in der Kantine?
trivia: Kantine comes from the Italian cantina (cellar).
Most words for specific rooms ending in -e are feminine.

english: I like eating currywurst best of all.
trivia: Am liebsten is the superlative form of gern.
Gericht can mean a "dish" or a "court of law."
Ge- prefixes often indicate neuter nouns.

english: One drinks café au lait for breakfast.
trivia: Milch + Kaffee. In Germany, it's often served in a bowl.
Compounds take the gender of the final word (der Kaffee).

word: Ich trinke im Durchschnitt 110 Liter Bier.
english: I drink 110 liters of beer on average.
sentence: Trinkst du viel Bier im Durchschnitt?

trivia: Related to the verb schneiden (to cut).
Neuter because das Wasser is neuter.

word: Ich hätte gern ein Wiener Schnitzel.
english: I would like a Wiener Schnitzel.
trivia: Hätte gern is a polite way to order.

english: I would like the chicken soup, please.

word: Ich nehme den Salat als Vorspeise.
english: I'll take the salad as an appetizer.

word: Ich esse Steak mit Kartoffeln als Hauptgericht.
english: I eat steak with potatoes as a main course.

trivia: Neuter because das Gericht is neuter.

english: I am drinking a glass of white wine.

sentence: Hast du ein Glas für mich?

trivia: Prost is for beer; Zum Wohl is more formal/for wine.
Use this to flag down the waiter.

sentence: Sagst du mir, wie das Essen war?
trivia: Common polite question after a meal.

word: Ich reserviere einen Tisch für vier Personen.
english: I am reserving a table for four people.
trivia: Personen is the plural of Person.

english: The restaurant is called Schnitzel Paradise.

word: Es ist von 12.00 bis 23.00 Uhr geöffnet.
trivia: Geöffnet is the past participle of öffnen.
A famous round chocolate from Salzburg.
Used in most European languages except English.
Also a colloquial word for a lightbulb.
Kuchen is simple; Torte is fancy.
